tuv.seg: Capital taxes following separation, divorce or dissolution
Cánacha Caipitiúla tar éis scartha/colscartha
Capital Gains Tax (CGT) is a tax on the profit made on the disposal of any asset and is payable by the person making the disposal
Séard é Cáin ar ghóthacháin chaipitiúla, ná cáin ar an mbrabús a dhéantar tar éis diúscairt aon sócmhainne agus bíonn an cháin le n-íoc ag an té atá i mbun diúscartha
Disposal can be by way of gift or sale
D'fhéadfadh gur trí dhíol nó trí thabhartas a dhéanfaí an diúscairt

Transfers of assets between spouses or civil partners are exempt from CGT. Transfers of assets between spouses or civil partners who are separated are exempt from CGT if they are made under a separation agreement or a court order
Ón dáta a bhfuil an chosúlacht air go mbeidh an scaradh buan, ní bhíonn sóchmhainní a aistrítear idir céilí, saor ón gCáin ar ghnóthacháin Chaipitiúla

Transfers of assets between spouses or civil partners on foot of a court order in a decree of divorce or dissolution are exempt from CGT but transfer of assets after the granting of the decree that are not ordered by the court are not

Ar an dóigh chéanna bíonn sócmhainní a aistrítear idir céilí mar thoradh ar Ordú Colscartha saor ón gcáin ach ní bhíonn aon aistrithe sócmhainní a tharlaíonn tar éis don fharógra Cholscartha a bheith déanta saor ón gcáin, ach amháin sa chás is gur ordaigh an chúirt iad
Separating couples should always seek specialist tax advice before entering into arrangements that have Capital Gains Tax implications
Ba cheart do lánúin atá ag scaradh comhairle shaineolach chánach a lorg, sula ndéanann siad aon socruithe a bhféadfadh impleachtaí Cain ar ghnóthachain chaipitiúla a bheith leo
Capital Acquisitions Tax (CAT) is a tax on gifts and inheritances received by a person
Séard é Cáin ar Fhaltais Chaipitiúla ná cáin ar thabhartais agus ar oidhreachtaí a fhaigheann duine
The person receiving the gift or inheritance pays the tax
Íocann an duine a fhaigheann an tabhartas, nó an t-oidhreacht, an cháin
The tax is paid on the open market value of the asset being received
Bíonn an cháin atá le n-íoc bunaithe ar an luach na sóchmhainne atá a fháil, ar an margadh oscailte
Transfers of assets between spouses or civil partners whether by way of gift or inheritance are exempt from CAT
Tá aistriú sochmhainní idir céilí saor ó cháin ar fhaltais chaipitiúla, is cuma cé acu tabhartas nó oidhreacht atá i gceist
Separation does not affect this exemption but divorce or dissolution does
Ní chuireann scaradh isteach air seo ach cuireann colscaradh

CAT does not apply to a property transfer, ordered by a court, between separated or divorced marriage partners but transfers of assets after the granting of the decree of divorce or dissolution that are not ordered by the court are not

Bíonn sócmhainní a aistrítear idir céilí do bhárr Órdú Cúirte i bhForógra Colscartha saor ón gcáin seo, ach ní bhíonn aon aistríthe sóchmhainní a tharlaíonn tar éis don Fhorógra Colscartha a bheith déanta saor ón gcáin, ach amháin sa chás is gur ordaigh an chúirt iad
Separating couples should always seek specialist tax advice before entering into arrangements that have Capital Acquisitions Tax implications
Ba cheart do lánúin atá ag scaradh comhairle ó shaineolaí cánach a lorg sula ndéanann siad aon socruithe a bhféadfadh impleachtaí Cáin Fhaltais Chaipitiúl a bheith leo
Stamp duty is a tax most often associated with the transfer of property whether by way of gift or sale
Baineann dleacht stampála, de ghnáth le aistriú maoine, trí thabhartas nó trí dhíolachán
Transfers of property between spouses or civil partners are exempt from stamp duty
Ní bhíonn dleacht stampála le n-íoc nuair a aistrítear maoin idir céilí
Transfers of property between spouses or civil partners who are separated or divorced are exempt from stamp duty if they are made following a court order
Ní bhíonn an dleacht le n-íoc ar aistriú maoine idir lanúin atá scartha nó colscartha má déanadh an t-aistriú mar thoradh ar ordú cúirte
There is more information on stamp duty here
Tá tuilleadh eolais sa doiciméad, Dleacht Stampála
